The support role came to exist because they could function without farming (allowing the ADC to take all farm in the lane).  

Champions were usually chosen for this role due to qualities such as their innate utility, innate durability or innate damage; they were not heavily reliant on gold, items or experience for their damage.

This is the primary purpose for having a support; they enable the gold-reliant ADC to hoard farm and are effective even with low gold income.
---------------------
Brand is a damage-oriented champion capable of filling the support role due to his low gold reliance.  He has some utility (stun, slow from Rylai's Crystal Scepter due to his passive), high base damages (scaling perfectly fine with little aside from magic penetration items) and easily procs the gold-generation from Spellthief's Edge.

He was used in pro-play and has been recognized as a viable support champion for over two years.

The "support" tag just means that they have supportive qualities and/or playstyle.  It does not necessarily mean that a champion HAS to be played as a support.
-------------------------
Nunu is a supportive jungler.  His kit is full of buffs and debuffs to enable his team and disable the enemy team through his utility.  

Ivern would also fall under this classification (and was in fact designed for it).
---------------
Orianna provides an MS buff and slow, a shield and her ultimate.  She generally plays by enabling her team and supporting then during skirmishes and teamfights even though she isn't necessarily a support.  

Lux and Anivia are also examples of mid-laners with supportive qualities.

Brand is a champion often played in the support position, even if he doesn't belong to the support class. His identity isn't that of a support in the same sense as Janna, Nami, Soraka, etc., but when he goes bot to support, he suffers from many of the same problems as anyone else who goes into the support position, i.e. sub-par gold and experience, unappetizing mandatory items, and the typical set of unfun restrictions imposed on supports, like not taking CS and having to go out alone to do the majority of the team's warding. He does have an advantage in that he's more independent and a lot more likely to get kills, but otherwise it's valid to test him out in order to find out what the support position needs.
